column7: Mirvac Group

column6: Entities included in the organization's sustainability reporting
column7: Mirvac Group comprises Mirvac Limited and Mirvac Property Trust and their controlled entities.

column6: Reporting period, frequency, and contact point
column7: Mirvac's report covers its performance for the year ended 30 June 2023.
Mirvac's report did not contain any restatements.
PwC provided limited assurance for Mirvac's report.

column6: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
column7: Mirvac is a leading urban property group.
Mirvac had 1,738 employees in 2023.
Mirvac's report did not include this information.
Mirvac's Board comprises 7 independent Non-Executive Directors.

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column13: As part of its role, the Nomination Committee develops succession plans for the Board, its Committees and the CEO/MD. In addition, the Committee annually assesses and reviews the performance of the Board, including the Non-Executive Directors. In developing board succession planning, the Nomination CommitteeÃ¢ÂÂs role includes identifying and assessing candidates for appointment to the Board and the boards of any subsidiaries that have non-executive director members.
column20: Succession plan, board succession planning, non-executive director

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column13: Before the appointment of any new Non-Executive Director, comprehensive checks are conducted to determine if the candidate has the capabilities needed and is fit and proper to undertake the role's responsibilities. These include background checks on character, education, career experience, criminal history and bankruptcy.

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column13: On appointment, each Non-Executive Director enters into a formal letter outlining their appointment's main terms, conditions and expectations. Before accepting the position, the candidate must confirm they have sufficient time to fulfil their obligations to Mirvac and provide details of their other commitments.

column6: Chair of the highest governance body
column7: Mr Rob Sindel is the chair of Mirvac's Board.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column13: Mirvac's Risk Management Framework is a core element of its corporate governance structure. It is in place to identify risks and implement mitigation plans to eliminate or reduce the impact on the Group meeting its strategic objectives. The Risk Framework outlines the governance processes, risk appetite, risk management accountabilities and operational resilience program.
column20: Risk Management Framework, governance structure, strategic objective

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column13: The governance framework at Mirvac provides a clear separation of the BoardÃ¢ÂÂs oversight functions, executive responsibilities, and accountability of the CEO/MD and management team. The Board Charter outlines the roles and responsibilities of the Board and management, including the matters reserved to the Board, and operates in conjunction with the Mirvac Constitutions and relevant laws.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column7: The Board is responsible for the overall governance of the Group and the effective oversight of management to build long-term value for securityholders and other stakeholders.

column13: The Board is responsible for assessing the independence of Non-Executive Directors upon appointment and each year with the support of an attestation from each of them. Non-executive directors are also obligated to disclose any personal interest that could materially interfere with, or reasonably be perceived to interfere with, the independent exercise of judgment or where they do not meet the BoardÃ¢ÂÂs guidelines for assessing independence.

column8: Conflicts of Interest and Related Party Transactions Policy
column13: Related party transactions and personal conflicts of interest are managed by the Conflicts of Interest and Related Party Transactions Policy, which sets out the GroupÃ¢ÂÂs position on how conflicts of interest in respect of personal conflicts of interest and corporate-related party transactions are identified and managed. This policy was last reviewed in December 2022.
column20: Conflicts of Interest and Related Party Transactions Policy, conflict of interest, related party transaction

column8: Continuous Disclosure and External Communications Policy
column13: Mirvac's Continuous Disclosure and External Communications Policy is specifically designed to support MirvacÃ¢ÂÂs commitment to a fully informed market. It sets out the processes to support compliance with the GroupÃ¢ÂÂs obligations concerning continuous disclosure, company announcements, and periodic reporting, including the roles and responsibilities of employees, the Continuous Disclosure Committee (CDC), and the Board.
column20: Continuous Disclosure and External Communications Policy, fully-informed market, company announcement

column6: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
column13: Once appointed, all new Non-Executive Directors are provided with an information pack, including governance policies and business information, and also participate in a formal induction program. This program includes meetings with the Chair, other Directors, the CEO/MD, members of the ELT and other senior executives (as appropriate) and office and site visits.
column20: Induction program, information pack, governance policy

column6: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
column13: The Board undertakes an annual assessment and review of its performance, with at least every second annual review being conducted with the assistance of an external consultant. The review process usually includes assessing the performance of the Board and Committees and each Director, with the results presented to the Board.

column7: The remuneration of non-executive directors is fixed and paid according to the role in which they serve on the Board and committees.

Non-Executive Directors are not eligible to participate in other remuneration components such as performance-related short-term or long-term incentives, options or variable remuneration and do not receive retirement benefits other than superannuation.
Mirvac's fixed and variable pay are both aimed at the market median, with remuneration opportunities for outstanding performance extending up to the 75th percentile of the market.

"Despite the current operating environment and volatility in markets, I believe we have an incredibly exciting future ahead of us. Our integrated and diversified business model has demonstrated resilience for more than 50 years and is further supported by a clear urban strategy and a passionate team of people. As our business and the operating environment continue to evolve, we remain as committed as ever to delivering quality for our customers, advancing our sustainability ambitions, innovating, and maintaining our unique and vibrant culture. I look forward to building on our vision on how we can continue to deliver exceptional places and experiences for millions of Australians. "

column13: Mirvac implemented a security trading policy that covers dealings in Mirvac securities by directors, employees, and their respective associates. The policy was last reviewed in December 2022. Directors and employees are only permitted to trade in Mirvac securities during designated trading windows, provided they do not have confidential price-sensitive information.
column20: Security Trading Policy, trading window, price-sensitive information

column13: Mirvac has a Fraud, Bribery & Corruption Policy, which outlines its commitment to preventing fraud, bribery, and corruption and provides guidance on managing these risks. The policy was last reviewed in June 2022, and reporting regarding investigations and their findings is provided to the Board through the ARCC.
column20: Fraud, Bribery & Corruption Policy, fraud, corruption, investigation

column13: Mirvac's Code of Conduct aims to articulate and make clear the standards of behaviour that Mirvac expects of everyone who represents Mirvac, including all Mirvac employees, Directors, contractors, labour-hire employees, suppliers and apprentices. The Board approved the Code, which was last reviewed in December 2022. Any materially adverse conduct that is inconsistent with the values, the Code or the desired culture of the Group is reported to the Board with oversight from the Human Resources Committee.
column20: Code of Conduct, adverse conduct, desired culture

column6: Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concern
column13: Mirvac has a whistleblower policy provides a mechanism for individuals to report concerns regarding potentially unethical, unlawful, or improper practices or behaviours. The Whistleblower Policy protects individuals reporting such matters in good faith. Access to MirvacÃ¢ÂÂs Whistleblower Hotline is also available to any third party, including suppliers, customers and securityholders who wish to report any concerns.
column20: Whistleblower Policy, improper practice, Whistleblower Hotline

column7: Mirvac's report did not include this information.
Mirvac is a member of the Property Council of Australia (PCA).

column13: Mirvac's securityholders may elect to receive all (or some) communications from the registry, Link Market Services, electronically, which is the most efficient way of staying informed. Generally, securityholders will no longer receive a hard copy of the annual report or documents for membersÃ¢ÂÂ meetings unless a copy is requested. The registry also gives securityholders the option to update their details electronically via their website, including changes of address or bank details for the payment of distributions.
column20: Link Market Services, securityholder, annual report

column13: Mirvac maintains an investor relations program to facilitate effective two-way communication with institutional investors, market analysts and brokers. This program allows investors, market analysts and brokers to understand MirvacÃ¢ÂÂs business, governance, financial performance and prospects.
column20: Investor relations program, institutional investor, market analyst

column13: Mirvac uses Net Promoter Score (NPS) to measure customer experience at key customer journey moments and periodically for ongoing customer relationships. In FY23, Mirvac largely maintained NPS across its asset classes, with feedback from tenants and partners continuing to shape its service.
column20: Net Promoter Score, customer experience, customer relationship

column7: In 2023, 5% of Mirvac's workforce were covered by an Award or were employed under an Enterprise Bargaining Agreement.
Mirvac conducts an annual assessment of its key risks to identify material, operational, and strategic matters that could impact the achievement of its strategy.
Mirvac's material topics are capital management, cyber risks, and social responsibility.
